Introduction
&rv; is a &ruby..ulink; interface to Verilog VPI. It lets you create complex Verilog &test-bench.ulink;es easily and wholly in Ruby.

Background
A pretend, virtual environment known as a &test-bench.ulink; is often used to verify the correctness or soundness of a Verilog model. The name test bench has its roots in electronics testing, where an engineer would sit at a lab bench—furnished with tools of measurement and manipulation, such as oscilliscopes, multi-meters (to measure voltage, amperage, and resistance), soldering irons, wire cutters, and so on—and manually verify an electronic component.
In our case, the test bench is defined by a Verilog simulator, a Verilog module, and &rv;. The first acts as the lab bench which provides measurement and manipulation tools. The second acts as the electronic component being verified by the engineer. The third acts as the engineer who measures, manipulates, and verifies the electronic component.
In a &rv; test bench, the Verilog simulator and &rv; take turns manipulating objects in the simulation and transfer control to each other when appropriate. The situation is similar to a pair of friends playing catch. One friend throws a ball to the other, and the other throws it back. Both are able to examine and modify the ball when in hand.
Initialization
Initialization of a &rv; test bench
illustrates the initialization process, which is described below.
First, the Verilog simulator initializes &rv; by invoking the $ruby_init(); system task/function, whose arguments represent the command-line invocation of the Ruby interpreter. For example, one would specify $ruby_init("ruby", "-w"); in Verilog to acheive the same effect as specifying ruby -w at a command-prompt.
Second, &rv; pauses the Verilog simulator and passes the arguments of the $ruby_init(); system task/function to a Ruby interpreter.
&background.step3;
Execution
Execution of a &rv; test bench
illustrates the execution process, which begins after the initialization process.
First, the Verilog simulator transfers control to Ruby-VPI by invoking the $ruby_relay(); system task/function.
Second, &rv; pauses the Verilog simulator and resumes the Ruby interpreter.
